text:
I did a comparison between the child server and the parent server and there are
301 updates that show as superseded on the child server (and appear to actually
be superseded) that all show with no superintendence (either direction) on the
parent server. I cannot decline them from the child (as it is just mirroring
the parent). The only way I can think of declining them would be to export that
list of 301 KB numbers and running a powershell script to automate the declines
on the parent (or manually decline them one by one on the parent).
%40googlegroups.com

metadata.topic: Re: WSUS supersedence info is broken

I did a comparison between the child server and the parent server and there are
301 updates that show as superseded on the child server (and appear to actually

%40googlegroups.com
metadata.email_text_original:
Re: WSUS supersedence info is broken 
You don't often get email from tom.alverson@gmail.com. Learn why this is
important [https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification] 
I did a comparison between the child server and the parent server and there are
301 updates that show as superseded on the child server (and appear to actually
be superseded) that all show with no superintendence (either direction) on the
parent server.  I cannot decline them from the child (as it is just mirroring
the parent).  The only way I can think of declining them would be to export that
list of 301 KB numbers and running a powershell script to automate the declines
on the parent (or manually decline them one by one on the parent).
Link: https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/patchmanagement/ed7b6f49-5a89-46b9-8b5c-8c3e8845f4dcn%40googlegroups.com
